definition[0]: continuing for only a limited period of time
example[1]: I’m living with my parents, but it’s only temporary.
example[2]: You might want to consider temporary work until you decide what you want to do.
example[3]: She was employed on a temporary basis.
definition[1]: intended to be used for only a limited period of time
example[5]: The bridge was erected as a temporary measure.
example[6]: I’ve got a temporary office job, but I hope I’ll find something more permanent soon.
example[7]: I’m sure the problem is only temporary.
definition[2]: temporary – used especially about arrangements or information that people may decide to change in the future. Also used about licences or governments which are only arranged to last for a short time
example[10]: Does the hotel accept provisional bookings?
example[11]: They have set a provisional date for the next meeting.
example[13]: In June, the rebels claimed to have formed a provisional government.
example[14]: Provisional figures yesterday from the Department of Transport showed that 4,274 people were killed last year — 6 percent fewer than the previous year.
definition[3]: temporary – used about something that you use for a short time until you can replace it with something better
example[15]: The Republicans will approve the one-month budget as a stopgap measure to keep the state operating.
example[16]: This is only a stopgap solution to the country’s debt problem.
definition[4]: temporary – used about an interest, thought, or feeling that is short and not very serious
example[17]: Tonight’s game will be exciting, even to those with only a passing interest in the sport.
example[18]: As a student, I didn’t give working in finance even a passing thought.
definition[5]: existing or popular for only a short time
example[19]: the ephemeral beauty of white snow on green trees and bare branches
example[20]: Many new words, particularly slang, are fleeting and ephemeral.
definition[6]: continuing for only a limited time, or staying somewhere for only a short time – used especially to say that something is always changing, or people only stay somewhere for a short time
example[22]: transient changes in the electrical properties of the neurons
example[23]: Arizona has a highly transient population.
definition[7]: a contract, job etc that is only intended to continue for a short time, for example until a particular piece of work is finished
definition[8]: an employee who is only employed for a short time, for example to do a particular piece of work
